There seems to be some confusion about what this notification is for. It's an accessibility feature rather than intended for letting power users pick what sites or pages they'd want to be redirected to. I don't know enough about this accessibility feature (that we don't seem to expose in about:preferences anymore :/ ) to tell if the target URL would be helpful for this feature's intended users.

comments.text:
Dao, just because it's documented under an "accessibility" heading doesn't mean it can't be improved. Please don't push back against a very useful and obvious enhancement request. It's not just about accessibility and the designers' "original intentions". Transparency and security are also important. URL redirectors are often used to mask links to malicious sites.

On another point, if source and target URL don't both fit in the available screen width, I favor displaying the target. Perhaps the prompt could be "Allow redirection to [target] from [source]?"

comments.text:
Comment on attachment 8973486
patch v2

I am OK with the wording, however I must say that I haven't seen this prompt appear in *years*. It used to be much more common in the pre-web app days in the mid 2000s. And I always considered it to be more of a security than an accessibility feature, since redirects are more a thing of, as was mentioned, probably malicious attempts. What was more bothersome for especially screen reader users were automatically *refreshing* pages. But I haven't seen any of those in years, either. :) Anyway, I'm OK with the wording, and am not against putting this change in, but ultimately, it's not really for me to decide. :)

As you can see from some of the other deps of bug 685496, this feature has a lot of issues. Unless it's impossible to replicate in a web extension for some reason (and then tweak it to actually do what people want), I'd be inclined to suggest we remove it outright. Accessibility tools have come a long way in the last 15 years, as has the web as a whole, and I don't think this feature is serving any real purpose anymore - certainly not the one for which it was designed.
